text: Regulation of human epsilon germline transcription : role of <extra_id_0> B-cell-specific activator protein <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Germline transcripts initiate from promoters upstream of the immunoglobulin switch region , and are necessary to target the appropriate switch region for recombination and switching .
Different cytokines activate transcription at the appropriate germline promoter .

Because binding sites for <extra_id_0> B-cell-specific activator protein <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> BSAP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) are located upstream of several switch regions in the immunoglobulin heavy chain gene cluster , <extra_id_0> BSAP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> might play a role in the regulation of germline transcription and isotype switching .
We investigated whether <extra_id_0> BSAP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> plays a role in the transcriptional regulation of the epsilon germline promoter in human B cells .

Our results showed that <extra_id_0> BSAP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> plays a role in both <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent induction and <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated upregulation of human epsilon germline transcription .

<extra_id_0> BSAP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is unique among the transcription factors that regulate epsilon germline expression , because it is B cell specific , and is at the merging point of two signalling pathways that are critical for IgE switching .
